children.message: You have a positive exponent
You have an integer exponent

You have an odd exponent, you're in the house of the odd powers. These are all odd functions that are symmetrical along the origin. They occupy quadrant 1 and 3, having an upwards and downwards arm. Graphs vary by the value of the exponent, larger exponents make the upwards slope of these graphs more dramatic

You have an even exponent, you're now in the house led by the parabolas. These are all even functions that are symmetrical along the y axis. They occupy quadrant 1 and 2, having 2 upwards arms in a U shape. Graphs vary by the value of the exponent, larger exponents make the upwards slope of these graphs more dramatic
You have a rational exponent
You have a denominator that is even

You'll be sorted into a small house. This one contains graphs that only occupy quadrant 1 and curve upwards like a parabola. Your house has a lot in common with the square roots, but the slope increases as x increases.

You belong to the house of sqrootius, named after the founder, the square root function. These functions are neither odd nor even, and only occupy quadrant 1. They increase quickly to (1,1), then curve downwards, having a smaller slope as x increases.
The denominator is odd
The numerator is odd

You have an odd/odd exponent, you're in the house of the odd-fraction powers. These are all odd functions that are symmetrical along the origin. They occupy quadrant 1 and 3, having an upwards and downwards arm. Graphs vary by the value of the exponent, larger exponents make the upwards slope of these graphs more dramatic
Ah, the S-house. These graphs are all odd functions that occupy quadrants 1 and 3, and are a cousin to the odd powers. However, they curve down instead of up, and look like an S.
The numerator is even

You have an even/odd exponent, you're now in the house led by the fraction-parabolas. These are all even functions that are symmetrical along the y axis. They occupy quadrant 1 and 2, having 2 upwards arms in a U shape. Graphs vary by the value of the exponent, larger exponents make the upwards slope of these graphs more dramatic

You belong in house Seagallus, a cousin to the parabolas. These are all even functions that are symmetrical along the y axis. They occupy quadrant 1 and 2, and have 2 downwards curving arms in either direction. Named after the mysterious seagull.
You have a negative exponent
You have an integer exponent

With a negative odd exponent, you will be sorted into the house of the hidden-rational. These are all odd functions that are symmetrical along the origin. They occupy quadrant 1 and 3, and have asymptotes on the x and y axis

With a negative even exponent, you will be sorted into the house of the geyser. These are all even functions that are symmetrical along the y-axis. They occupy quadrant 1 and 2, and have asymptotes on the x and y axis
You have a rational exponent

With a negative over even exponent, you will be sorted into one of the most elusive houses of the school, the rampuess. These are functions are rational versions of even root functions. They only occupy quadrant 1, and have asymptotes on the x and y axis
The denominator is odd

With a negative odd/odd exponent, you will be sorted into the house of the hidden-rational. These are all odd functions that are symmetrical along the origin. They occupy quadrant 1 and 3, and have asymptotes on the x and y axis

With a negative even/odd exponent, you will be sorted into the house of the geyser. These are all even functions that are symmetrical along the y-axis. They occupy quadrant 1 and 2, and have asymptotes on the x and y axis
Wait, you have a zero exponent. You are just a horizontal line in disguise! EXPELL THIS IMPOSTER IMMEDIATELY! (Refresh the page to start over)
